titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dr. William Griffith papers, 1960-2014 MS1006.UA

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: William B. Griffith joined the George Washington University faculty in July 1964 and was Elton Professor of Philosophy and Public Policy. The collection contains his work in the department, as well as other professional activities such as the faculty senate and papers given at conferences.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William B. Griffith was Elton Professor of Philosophy and Public Policy at George Washington University. He joined the GW faculty in July 1964. He devised and taught more than 30 courses during his tenure, with a special emphasis on ethical theory, philosophical aspects of public policy issues, economic justice and logic. Dr. Griffith served several terms as chair of the Department of Philosophy and was one of the longest-serving members of the Faculty Senate, where he occupied several different leadership positions.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William B. Griffith was Elton Professor of Philosophy and Public Policy at George Washington University. William Byron Griffith was born in Fort Worth and was a 1958 graduate of the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind. After studying at the University of Louvain in Belgium on a Fulbright scholarship, he received master's (1962) and doctoral degrees (1963) in philosophy from Yale University. He served in the Army before joining GWU in July 1964.

His research interests and publications focused on the application of theories of distributive justice to environmental policy, welfare policy, tax policy, and the regulation of business. He devised and taught more than 30 courses during his tenure, with a special emphasis on ethical theory, philosophical aspects of public policy issues, economic justice and logic. He was the principal architect and long-serving director of the MA Program in Philosophy and Public Policy, the first of its kind in the United States.

Dr. Griffith served several terms as chair of the Department of Philosophy and was one of the longest-serving members of the Faculty Senate, where he occupied several different leadership positions, including chair of the Executive Committee, and chair of the Committee on Fiscal Planning and Budgeting. He also served as the redoubtable parliamentarian for Columbian College faculty meetings through the fall of 2013.
He died at midnight on February 10, 2014.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some materials are restricted, such as student information and salary information. Please check with the University Archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Materials in this collection may be governed by copyright. For activities that the researcher determines fall under fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. Researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights, determining if the intended re-use falls under fair use, and obtaining approval from the copyright holder if the intended use does not fall under fair use. Please contact Special Collections if the copyright status of the materials you wish to reuse is unclear. Staff will provide additional information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:

Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository. Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and content notes
scopecontent.p: Records relating to the classes that Dr. Griffith was involved with during his tenure at GWU. He devised and taught more than 30 courses during his tenure, with a special emphasis on ethical theory, philosophical aspects of public policy issues, economic justice and logic

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The letters of recommendations are restricted for 25 years from the date written.

did.unittitle: Ethics and Policy - Campaign Finance Clippings
Philosophy and Ethics topics and courses

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: Program description, specific classes in Philosophy and ethics such as 51, 131, 132, 801, 230, rights theory, feminist, more development, welfare and food stamps. Documents within the folder include handouts, syllabi, bibliographies

scopecontent.head: Scope and content notes
scopecontent.p: Box contains folders pertaining to prospective students, search committees for the department, general philosophy department records, specific classes such as 6230, and policy guides for students, admininstration, applications, inquiries, course description and jobs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and content notes
scopecontent.p: Philosophy classes - 230 (2004-2007) with student evaluationss; criminal justice and discrimination; family support act of 1988; lawsuits that had to do with philosophical ideas; justice and equality from 1974, conference on social security from 1986. Ethics and sociology issues such as regulation, academic, and professionalism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and content notes
scopecontent.p: Ethics and policy - discrimination, affirmative action, general data, views and economic theories, justice, equality and gender, and different legal cases. Specific classes such as 131, 132, 801, 198 and 235.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Philosophy courses such as 235, philosophy and business, philosophy and public interest, and other related topics to these classes.

did.unittitle: Lecture Material for Ethics and Philosophy Courses

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted for 25 years from date of creation.

did.unittitle: University Facilitating Fund Request for Proposals

Expressive Meaning, Race and the Law
Notes on organizing a research paper
Guidance on participation in class discussion
Public Policy PhD Field Exam Questions

did.physdesc: This box contains a wide variety of topics in the realm of ethics, economy and philosophy such as professional accountability, hedge funds, taxes, government and public administration, legal ethics, medicine, and social work. The papers appear to be research that was sometimes used in Dr. Griffith's classes.

Notes and writings on philosophical topics such as logic, logicism, finitism, Godel's Theorem, the history and philosophy of math and logic, valued logic and the philosophy of language. These appear to be copies of articles or presentations that Griffith attended and made notes. Some of these may be notes that Griffith himself took while a student.

Notes and writings on philosophical topics such as symbolic logic, logical theory, advanced logic, logic and social change, logic of choice and decisions, cryptography, and axiomatics. These appear to be copies of articles or presentations that Griffith attended and made notes. Some of these may be notes that Griffith himself took while a student.

scopecontent.head: Scope and contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Griffith was one of the longest-serving members of the Faculty Senate, where he occupied several different leadership positions, including chair of the Executive Committee, and chair of the Committee on Fiscal Planning and Budgeting. He also served as the redoubtable parliamentarian for Columbian College faculty meetings through the fall of 2013.

scopecontent.p: University policies - code of academic integrity (1996); disabilities, media relations, Gelman fines, student rights and responsibilities, requirements in syllabi, and Trachtenberg prize. Also includes the Faculty Senate trustees committee and development of alumni, 2000-2001

scopecontent.p: This box contains materials related to presentations at conferences, seminars and symposia. The folders contain the presentation themselves, notes, abstracts, correspondence and other related items.

did.physdesc: This box contains a variety of personal writings on philosophy and ethics topics. It includes reprints, drafts, copies, and other parts of the writing process.
